intro: Cascarilla calycina, commonly known as the Mexican tamarind, is a flowering plant native to Central America and parts of the Caribbean. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae and is characterized by its woody stems and opposite leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, fragrant white flowers that bloom in clusters, followed by yellowish fruits containing edible seeds. Its bark and leaves have been traditionally used in herbal medicine for their potential anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties.
